Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Improving Performance in Passive RFID Networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project focuses on commercialization of new techniques that improve communication performance of battery-less, passive radio frequency identification (RFID)-based systems. Such passive communication is already used in many industries and application due to its benefits of small size, wireless communication capabilities, wireless powering of the device, lack of battery and related maintenance, easy deployment, environment friendly (no battery pollution), etc. However, this good characteristic comes with a drawback: short range and interference when a large number of devices is deployed in a small area. This prevented employment of RFID in applications where large number of tags is to be read and also produces hesitations in future usage of RFID systems in Internet of Things (IoT). Yet there is large market potential. The current (in 2015), passive RFID market is over $8 billion worldwide ranging from retail industry and tracking object to health care and Internet of Things (IoT). Specifically, UHF RFID field is expecting to have over $ 9.5 billion market by 2018. This market craves for increasing read rates, extending range, material compatible tags and security. The proposed solution will remedy a low read rate problem and security concerns in RFID market while extending the communication range and providing more power for advanced, smart applications. The proposed technique can be used for UHF RFID tags to increase read rates in warehouses (e.g., Walmart) and extend the range in wireless sensor networks (e.g., NASA). Considering the individual specification of these products it is expected that RFID manufactures and consumers will welcome the introduction of these products to the market.

The proposed work includes discovery of potential customers and their needs with respect to RFID technology. In contrast to existing work that often focuses on purely technical advancements, the proposed effort aims at refining the proposed solution for improving the performance RFID such that the customers needs are addressed. The proposed solutions aim at combining four novel approaches to developing a more efficient RFID tag including:
(1) novel RFID tag antenna design that maximizes backscatter signal by 200% over existing designs;
(2) flexible impedance matching network for loading the RFID tag antenna that allows dynamic tuning of antenna properties to compensate for mutual coupling and interference from environment;
(3) collaborative scheme where adjacent RFID tags improve communication performance by using both the antenna and impedance tuning circuitry to minimize their destructive interference and coupling; and
(4) introducing a new operation state for RFID tags in a network fashion in that tags can receive signal from the environment but they produce minimum scattering (interference) to the environment. The customer discovery will ensure that the resulting solution will be commercially viable.
Furthermore, the team will develop a prototype and proof-of-concept demonstration that will target the customer needs and show the value proposition.

Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

Performance_Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on discovering the best commercialization path for the reliable universal RFID tag that helps companies and organization to regain their capital more quickly through maintaining 99.5% accuracy in inventory, and reducing RFID fixed infrastructure cost by 50% through increased communication range of the proposed RFID tag design.

     The main outcomes of the projects include:
  1. Professional training and experiential learning on best practices in technology transfer for the project team of 5 members including 2 female.
  2. Increased publicity and dissemination of knowledge that was supported by NSF - over 100 targeted interviews have been conducted with potential users of the team's technology. Also, the technical details have been presented at the leading IEEE RFID 2016 conference
  3. Two patent application for the technology developed using the NSF support. The project funding supported better outreach to potential users of the technology and the teams continues discussions on licensing technology to the RFID-related companies.
    After the project concluded the team is pursuing commercialization path through small scale demonstration deployment of the universal RFID tag. That would provide strong evidence of benefits of our technology thus allowing to convince large RFID technology providers to integrate it into the standard, mass produced RFID devices and tags.

    Overall the team gained valuable skills and identified the best pathway for commercialization. After the cohort, the team worked on developing a prototype of the universal RFID tag for demonstration purposes. We employed WISP4 and WISP5 open hardware platforms to test and demonstrate the capabilities of he technology. Furthermore, we believe such a small scale demonstration deployment of the universal RFID tag would provide necessary evidence of benefits that would convince large RFID technology providers to integrate it into the standard, mass produced RFID devices and tags.

Additionally, the future plans include test deployment of the tag prototype in realistic scenarios. We are collaborating with an aerospace manufacturing and an aircraft maintenance-and-service companies to showcase the technology for both manufacturing of aircrafts and their maintenance.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project focused on discovering the best commercialization path for the reliable universal RFID tag that helps companies and organization to regain their capital more quickly through maintaining 99.5% accuracy in inventory, and reducing RFID fixed infrastructure cost by 50% through increased communication range of the proposed RFID tag design. The main outcomes of the projects include: Professional training and experiential learning on best practices in technology transfer for the project team of 5 members including 2 female. Increased publicity and dissemination of knowledge that was supported by NSF - over 100 targeted interviews have been conducted with potential users of the team's technology. Also, the technical details have been presented at the leading IEEE RFID 2016 conference Two patent application for the technology developed using the NSF support. The project funding supported better outreach to potential users of the technology and the teams continues discussions on licensing technology to the RFID-related companies. After the project concluded the team is pursuing commercialization path through small scale demonstration deployment of the universal RFID tag. That would provide strong evidence of benefits of our technology thus allowing to convince large RFID technology providers to integrate it into the standard, mass produced RFID devices and tags. Overall the team gained valuable skills and identified the best pathway for commercialization. After the cohort, the team worked on developing a prototype of the universal RFID tag for demonstration purposes. We employed WISP4 and WISP5 open hardware platforms to test and demonstrate the capabilities of he technology. Furthermore, we believe such a small scale demonstration deployment of the universal RFID tag would provide necessary evidence of benefits that would convince large RFID technology providers to integrate it into the standard, mass produced RFID devices and tags. Additionally, the future plans include test deployment of the tag prototype in realistic scenarios. We are collaborating with an aerospace manufacturing and an aircraft maintenance-and-service companies to showcase the technology for both manufacturing of aircrafts and their maintenance.
